annotation.text: Allows care events to be attached to other care events
Property-contextConductionStyle: I
Allows linking records to encounters, condition and care-based compositions. Useful for searching and navigation of the patient's record.

A care composition is a record with two purposes. It indicates that care of a given type has occurred or is occurring. It also acts as a collector for the events that happened during care, including who is responsible for the care provided.
IMMUNIZATION INTERPRETATION.REFERENCED DATA
Allows care compositions to be uniquely identified and referenced, and is therefore mandatory
Unique identifier of an encounter, condition or care-based collection.
IMMUNIZATION INTERPRETATION.REFERENCED DATA
EPHS: vocab concepts needed for LAB ID, Special Considerations ID etc.
Allows care compositions to be captured and categorized at different levels of abstraction, and is therefore mandatory.

Identifies the kind of composition represented. Examples include encounters ("Emergency Encounter", "Long Term Care Encounter", etc), health condition (episode)-based collections (e.g. "Diabetes", "Hypertension", etc) and general care-based collections such as "gynecological care".
A patient referenced only by identifier. Used when conveying patient session tokens where identity resolution has already occurred
Property-contextConductionStyle: I
Used when patienty identity confirmation is handled as a distinct business process rather than as part of each transaction. Allows transactions to be linked to a specific patient.
A person who is receiving or may receive healthcare services and has had their identity previously confirmed

An identified healthcare provider resolvable against a provider registry confirmed by basic demographic information. Includes non-licensed providers such as receptionists.
Property-contextConductionStyle: I
Critical to tracking responsibility and performing follow-up. The CMET supports both licensed providers as well as non-licensed providers such as technicians, receptionists, etc.
The person assigned to carry out the associated action (linked by a participation) and/or the organization/group under whose authority they are acting.
Allows unique identification of the person which can be critical for authentication, permissions, drill-down and traceability and is therefore mandatory.
Unique identifier the person involved in the action.
Allows lookup on college website, confirmation of identity, etc. Regulations occasionally require license numbers to be specified as part of clinical records.
If the identifier used in the root of the CMET is the same as the license number, the license number should be sent in both places.
The license number issued to the provider and relevant to the current action.
Used for determining responsibility and potentially confirming permissions.
Identifies the organization or group on whose behalf the action is performed.
Allows the organization to be referenced when determining privileges and for drill-downs to retrieve additional information. Because of its importance, the attribute is mandatory.
A unique identifier for the organization
Allows for human recognition of the organization as well as confirmation of the identifier. As a result, the attribute is mandatory.
Identifies the name of the organization
Even when an organization is taking responsibility, a person is generally involved in the work.
Describes the person actually involved in the action.
This is a human-readable name and is essential for validation of the person. As a result, the attribute is mandatory
The name of the involved person.
An identified healthcare provider including basic demographic and contact information extracted from a provider registry. Includes non-licensed providers such as receptionists
Property-contextConductionStyle: I
Id mandatory for physicians
Critical to tracking responsibility and performing follow-up. The CMET supports both licensed providers as well as non-licensed providers such as technicians, receptionists, etc.
All attributes other than the various identifiers are expected to be retrieved from the provider registry.
The person organization assigned to carry out the associated (linked by a participation) action and/or the organization under whose authority they are acting.
Allows unique identification of the person which can be critical for authentication, permissions, drill-down and traceability and is therefore mandatory.
Unique identifier the person involved in the action.
Provides context around the actions of the participant and is therefore mandatory.
Indicates the "kind" of healthcare participant, such as "physician", "dentist", "lab technician", "receptionist", etc.

annotation.text: This is the most commonly used piece of contact information and is returned here to avoid unnecessary queries of the provider registry.
Indicates phone and/or e-mail addresses at which the healthcare worker can be reached.
Identifies the organization on whose behalf the action is performed.
Identifies the type of organization on whose behalf the action was taken
Allows lookup on college website, confirmation of identity, etc. Regulations occasionally require license numbers to be specified as part of clinical records.

If the identifier used in the root of the CMET is the same as the license number, the license number should be sent in both places.

Detailed information about the status and effective period of licenses must be retrieved from the provider registry.
The license number issued to the provider and relevant to the current action.
A unique identifier for the organization
Allows for human recognition of the organization as well as confirmation of the identifier. As a result, the attribute is mandatory.
Identifies the name of the organization
This is a human-readable name and is thus essential for both display and validation of the person. As a result, the attribute is mandatory.
The name of the participating person.

This role describes specific qualifications that may be held the provider as a result of training or experience, but having no legal force. Example: a medical degree or diploma. The current model does not include role attributes such as name, addr and telecom because there are no known use cases in this domain where this role is contactable.
A code for the degree or educational rank that the credential specifies. May also apply to an Expertise type.
An application identifier by a name and responsible jurisdiction name
Property-contextConductionStyle: I
Provides context about the record and its management.
Identification of the EHR infostructure responsible for the storage and management of the record.
Allows repositories to be uniquely identified for linking or grouping purposes and is therefore mandatory.
A unique identifier for the EHR repository.
Provides a human-readable name for the repository and is therefore mandatory
The name of the repository which is responsible for maintaining the record. E.g. "Ontario Health Respository #3"
Establishes business context for determining custodianship, and is therefore mandatory.
The name of the jurisdiction that is responsible for the EHR infostructure that contains and manages the record.
Indicates an identified organization with basic demographic informationresolvable against or referenced from a provider registry. Used when the specific device or provider involved is not known.
Property-contextConductionStyle: I
Critical to tracking responsibility and performing follow-up.
The organization under whose authority the associated action (linked by a participation) was performed.
Used for determining responsibility and potentially confirming permissions.

Used to convey reason for therapy including both condition-based and 'other' indications.
Property-contextConductionStyle: I
Allows separation of conditions from symptoms from other forms of indication.
Describes diagnosis-related indications
Identifies this measurement as a type of diagnosis and is therefore mandatory.
Identifies the type of problem described.

Allows cross-checking the use of a therapy against its indication. Also allows analysis of best practices, etc. This is the attribute that actually identifies the indication and is therefore mandatory.

[UseCommon CD]
A coded form of the problem that is the reason for the current action.
Must have at least one of code or text
Allows separation of conditions from symptoms from other forms of indication.
Describes indications that are not diagnosis or symptom-related (e.g. contrast agents)

EPHS: vocab proposal needed for simple concepts of i) sign or symptom related to investigation disease ii) sign or symptom not related to investigation disease. EPHS: act.code value needed for encounter reason; reason for treatment; immunization interpretation reason
Allows for coded representation of a non-condition based indication such as administration of a contrast agent for a lab test.
A code indicating some other action which is the reason for a therapy.
Provides ability to describe indication without labeling it a diagnosis or symptom. Attribute as free form text is the only information allowed.
A textual description of an indication not meant to be either diagnosis or symptom.
Allows notes to be attached to clinical objects
Property-contextConductionStyle: I

Public Health requires all clinical notes to be 'verified' by a responsible party if not created by physician in charge. This model conveys the correct semantics, but is inconsistent with other uses of "author" participation in POIZ models. Any changes here will have to be reconciled with other projects using this same cmet.
Allows various Providers to attach comments to an existing record, and thus improving cross-provider communications.

This is a list of comments made about the record by providers. Information captured here includes the provider making the comments; and excludes information that would render the record invalid. This information will only be seen when another provider reviews the record. Urgent or targeted messages should be sent using a different mechanism (e.g. phone).

Allows a provider to attach comments to objects for communication. This attribute is mandatory because there's no point in having a note class unless there's actually content in the note.

Language is supported to allow grouping or filtering comments based on language
Free text comments. Additional textual iinformation entered about an object.

Possible RIM issue: the use of author participation in this model is inconsistent with author participations used in other models, e.g author participation in Immunization event model (POIZ_MT030050CA).
Allows tracking of who made what comment. This attribute is marked as 'mandatory' because the provider posting a comment must always be known.
Identifies the provider responsible for the content of the note.

Identifies timing of the annotation for sorting and for audit purposes.

This attribute is mandatory because the time of creation of the annotation will always be known.
The date and time at which the note was posted.

An identified service delivery location confirmed by name and type resolvable against the service delivery location registry. Includes optional coordinate information to indicate the present location of a mobile SDL.

Allows capturing of GPS, legal land, and/or range-meridian coordinates of a location for subsequent proximity searching. Also allows the capture of disaster sites and other non-dedicated service delivery locations which may not have a traditional address. (These locations are typically registered for public health purposes.)

The association is optional because not all systems will choose to support capturing information at this level.

Identifies service delivery locations contained within the described "parent" service delivery location.
Provides context about what the capabilities of the component service delivery location are. Allows for unique identification of a sub-location and is therefore mandatory.
Describes the 'type' of component service delivery location. For example, a hospital might contain a laboratory or a community clinic.
Provides a human-readable label for the location and is therefore mandatory. In general, names of sub-locations will be unique within their containing location.

Provides a human-readable label for the location and is therefore mandatory. In general, names of sub-locations will be unique within their containing location.

Identifies what kind of issue was detected or is being managed.

This is mandatory so as to ensure that one issue type can be distinguished from another.

A coded value that is used to distinguish between different kinds of issues. Types of issue include: unrecognized identifiers, permission issues, drug-drug contraindications, drug-allergy alerts, duplicate therapies, etc.

ZPE.4
Lets providers see textual explanation of the issue.
A free form textual description of a detected issue. This textual information is provided to either augment the coded information or in place of the coded information.

Allows the provider to make informed decision on the importance and criticality of an issue. May also be used by the DIS to determine the order of returning issues. Attribute is mandatory because every issue needs to be prioritized.
A coded value denoting the importance of a detectable issue. Valid codes are: I - for Information, E - for Error, and W - for Warning.
A_DetectedMedicationIssue
It allows overriding of the detected issue

The processes and procedures employed by providers to resolve clinical and business issues between the action being performed and additional information already in the patient's record or system business rules.
ManagedContraindication.State
OverrideReason.reason
D65(when dealing with clinical indication overrides, otherwise use overrides in ControlAct wrapper.
Intervention Codes
ZPS.8
DUR/PPS.440-E6
DUR/PPS.441-E6
Claim.420-DK
A_DetectedMedicationIssue

Ensures consistency in description of management actions.

This is mandatory so as to ensure distinction between different kinds of management.
Indicates the kinds of management actions that have been taken, depending on the issue type.
Allows additional clinical detail to be conveyed that are important clinically and not conveyed by the code.
Additional free-text details describing the management of the issue.
Allows issues to be overridden and provides for enhanced clinical communication about issues.
Indicates how the issue has been managed.
A warning or error being overridden not related to clinical information
Property-contextConductionStyle: C
OverrideReason.provider
ManagedContraindication.provider
A_DetectedMedicationIssue
Part of the audit record, but may not always be known for historical managements.
Identifies the provider who created the management of the issue.
ManagedContraindication.CreationDate
Part of the audit record but not always available and therefore only marked as 'populated'.
The date and time on which the provider used this management for the issue in the past.
Provides a list of issues that have been detected.
This is the list of clinical and business-rule issues that have been detected and recorded involving the current action.
Contraindication.crossSensitive (if code is related reaction dected issue then crossSensitive is 'True')
Distinguishes between DAI, DDI, DosageCheck, DPD, and Duplicate Therapy Contraindications
Contraindication.DosageContraType

E06(for contraindications errors are handled at transmission or controlAct wrapper level)

Interaction Type
ZDU.9.1(PLYPHRM)
ZDU.10.1 (PLYDOC)
DUR/PPS.439-E4
A_DetectedMedicationIssue

Identifies what kind of issue was detected.

This is mandatory so as to ensure that one issue type can be distinguished from another.

A coded value that is used to distinguish between different kinds of issues. Types of issue include: unrecognized identifiers, permission issues, drug-drug contraindications, drug-allergy alerts, duplicate therapies, etc.
Contraindication.DDIDescription
E20(for contraindication errors are handled at transmission or controlact wrapper level)
ZPE.4
Lets providers see textual explanation of the issue.
A free form textual description of a detected issue. This textual information is provided to either augment the coded information or in place of the coded information.

Allows the provider to make informed decision on the importance and criticality of an issue. May also be used by the DIS to determine the order of returning issues. Attribute is mandatory because every issue needs to be prioritized.

Used to identify XPath referencesthat indicate which attributes in a message instance were involved in the issue.
A_DetectedMedicationIssue
Presents alternatives for how the issue could be managed or has been managed in the past.
The processes and procedures employed by providers to resolve clinical conflicts between the action being performed and additional information already in the patient's record.

Indicates the kinds of management actions that can be taken, based on the issue type.
Allows additional clinical detail to be conveyed that are important clinically and not conveyed by the code.
Additional free-text details describing the management of the issue.
Allows past or potential managements to be displayed to assist providers in determining how to manage a particular issue.
Indicates how the issue could be managed.
Contraindication.ManagementRequired (True, if this association is present)

Lets applications distinguish between minor issues that require no management versus those that need management to successfully process the request.

The association behaves as a mandatory attribute where the presence of the association indicates 'true', while the absence of indicates 'false'.
Information that indicates whether or not a detected issue needs to be managed.
Used to convey consent overrides and keywords associated with a particular trigger event
Property-contextConductionStyle: C

Different consents (or even keywords) may be needed to access different types of patient information (e.g. demographics, medications, allergies, lab results). Understanding the type of information the consent applies to is critical, and therefore the attribute is mandatory.
The type of patient information that can be accessed or modified.
Authorization.Person
Authorization.signatory(PT)
Consent can be provided by the patient or representative or the provider.
Indicates that the consent was provided by the patient or representative.
Verbal consents may trigger a higher level of auditing.
Indicates whether the patient's consent is written or verbal.
Allows providers who know the keyword to access information protected by patient keywords.
Indicates the keyword appropriate to the action being performed by the message.
Authorization.signatory(PROV)
Clinical circumstances may demand that a patient's information be accessed without consent to ensure patient safety.
Indicates that information access was approved by a provider rather than a patient. I.e. This is an override rather than an actual consent, and is used for the purposes of 'breaking the glass' only.
One and only one of author2 (Consenter) and author1 (Provider) must be specified.

Provides authorization to record and/or view patient information.

Indicates the consent or keyword used to authorize access or update, including a reason for access; May also be used to override access restriction to the information ('break the glass') on a message by message basis. May be required on a Prescription Request to indicate a keyword for DUR processing.
The keywords will not be passed from prescriber to dispenser by the DIS.
Information pertaining to a patient's agreement/acceptance to have his/her clinical information electronically stored and shared.
Authorization.formNumber
Provides a traceable audit link between a physical consent form and its electronic record
A unique identifier for a specific consent for a patient.
Authorization.dataType
Authorization.endTime (high)
Most consents are not open-ended, to ensure the patient retains a level of control.
Indicates the time that the consent will expire. 'Low' is effective time and 'High' is end time.
If author1 (provider) is specified, reason code must be specified.
Authorization.reason (mnemonic)
Authorization.comment (original text)
Important for audit purposes
Indicates a reason for overriding a patient's consent rules.
Allows discrete control over different types of information.
Defines the types of information permission is being granted to access.

Indicates who is receiving consent to view information.

This participation is marked as "populated" as receiver must be specified when keyword is involved.
Identifies the beneficiary of the consent as being a Provider or Service Location.
Essential for knowing what patient the consent is for, and therefore mandatory.
The patient's record the consent is associated with.

References a person with a relationship to the record target where that person can be found in a client registry using an identifier and confirming demographics. Includes situations where the relationship is 'self'
Property-contextConductionStyle: I
Important for tracking source of information for decision making and other actions taken on behalf of a patient.

Describes a person (other than a health-care provider or employee) who is providing information and making decision on behalf of the patient, in relation to the delivery of healthcare for the patient. E.g. Patient's mother. Also used with a relationship of "self" when the patient themselves is providing the care.

The expectation is that the person can be found in the client registry.

A coded value indicating how the responsible person is related to the patient. If the code is "SELF", it indicates that the action was performed by the patient themselves.

Property-contextConductionStyle: I
Allows referencing the GPS legal or range-meridian coordinates of a location
Property-contextConductionStyle: C
Used to geographically describe the location. There is no point specifying a coordinate system without identifying the coordinates. Therefore this association is mandatory.
Identifies the relative position of the location along a particular axis
Some locations cannot be described by postal addresses. Also, geographic coordinates allow calculation of distances and proximity
Allows the capturing of a physical location according to a particular coordinate system, such as GPS, legal designation (lot, block, plan), range-meridian, etc.
Essential for interpretting the specified coordinates and therefore mandatory
Identifies the coordinate system inclusive of any transformation projections.
Defines the position of the location
Describes the postion of the location along a specific axis.
Acts as the "name" in the name-value pair that expresses a coordinate and is therefore mandatory

Identifies the individual coordinate in the coordinate system inclusive of any transformations or projections.

Examples of corordinate types are: meridian, range, township, longitude, latitude, lot, block, etc.
Actually expresses the location along the axis. Because unknown axis positions can simply be omitted, this attribute is mandatory.
Denotes the individual coordinate value as a a physical quantity. For example, lot number, range number, latitude, etc.
Property-contextConductionStyle: I

As a request, refers to the event to be acted upon or which has been acted upon.

As a response, may be used to indicate the identifier assigned to a created object.
References an existing event record by identifier.
Allows the event record to be uniquely referenced and is therefore mandatory.
The identifier assigned by the central system (EHR) to the Event record being referred to.

packageLocation.name: MCAI_MT700211AB
packageLocation.desc: Event Request Wrapper - Human Initiated Patient Specific With Administrative Act Payload

annotation.text: Property-contextConductionStyle: C
Identifies or conveys the distinguishing information about the data being manipulated.
Contains the content being conveyed or manipulated by this trigger event (e.g. the prescription, the allergy, the lab result, etc.).
If AuthorizationToken is specified and communicates author, the bare AuthorRole class must be specified, otherwise the R_ActingPerson CMET must be specified.
Critical for auditing and for validating permissions and therefore mandatory.

Choice of Patient CMET is as follows:

1. 'identified' when supporting Patient Session Tokens.

2. 'informational' when passing through non Client- Registry patient for PHS or similar processing.

3. 'identified-confirmable' otherwise.
Indicates the person responsible for the event that caused this message.
Value should always be AUT
The time a change is made is a critical piece of audit information and is therefore mandatory.

The time the person responsible for the event made the decision for it to occur. This may be different than the time the change became effective. (E.g. If a provider decides today to put a prescription on hold starting next Tuesday, the time of creation would be today and the change effective period would be next Tuesday.)

This date can be back-dated.
May have ramifications for the audit trail and reliability of the information.
Indicates how the person who recorded the event became aware of it.. E.g. Verbal, written, fax, etc.
Digital signatures may be needed for authentication of message content. The attribute is marked as optional because it is not yet clear whether there is a use-case for this, or where it will be used.
Indicates the formal digital signature of the message content.

This is a messaging artifact used by HL7 to allow the time, signiture and method to be captured when the author is not sent. This will happen in circumstances where the author information is sent as part of the authentication token.

If specified, then the concepts covered by the token must not be specified (i.e. at least one participation of author, dataEnterer, responsibleParty, location and dataEntryLocation must not be specified)
Only one of Id or Text must be specified.
Conveys information related to the individuals and/or locations involved with the action in situations where the authentication happens on a one-time basis rather than on a per-message basis.

Conveys an authentication token associated with the event.

The token may represent one or all of the following concepts: author, dataEnterer, responsibleParty, location and dataEntryLocation.
GUIDs are an effective way of conveying a temporary authentication token

An authorization token expressed as a GUID.

The Authorization token may represent the concepts of author, data enterer, supervisor (responsible party), responsible location and/or data entry location.
Some systems may choose to use a hashcode or other approach to token construction.

An authentication token expressed as a non-GUID string.

The Authorization token may represent the concepts of author, data enterer, supervisor (responsible party), responsible location and/or data entry location.
Allows linking records to encounters, condition and care-based compositions. Useful for searching and navigation of the patient's record.

A care composition is a record, which summarizes the events that happened during care including who is responsible for the care provided.

Examples include encounters, health condition (episode)-based collections and general care-based collections such as "gynecological care".
Key to understanding what action a message represents.
There may be constraints on the usage of the effectiveTime and reasonCode attributes in the definition of the interaction or the trigger events which are conveyed with this wrapper.
Identifies the action that resulted in this message being sent.
Allows the event to be referenced (for undos) and also indicates whether multiple interactions were caused by the same triggering event. Also used for audit purposes.
Identifier needs to be persisted by receiving applications, except for queries (queries cannot be retracted or undone).
A unique identifier for this particular event assigned by the system in which the event occurred.
This is mandatory because it is essential to understanding the meaning of the event.
Identifies the trigger event that occurred.
Required for completeness of specification.
Describes the status of the control act, which is always complete (it happened).

The time an event becomes effective may differ from the time the event is recorded (i.e. it may be in the future or the past). For events such as 'suspend', an intended end date may also be indicated.
Indicates the time the event (e.g. query, change, activation) should begin and occasionally when it should end.
Allows identifying a reason for a specific action, such as 'reason for hold' or 'reason for accessing information'.
The domain associated with this attribute will vary for each interaction and will be noted as part of the interaction description.
Identifies why this specific message interaction (e.g. query, activation request, modification request) occurred.

Important for audit information and determining permissions.

The association is optional because in some jurisdictions this information will be conveyed as part of the authentication token.
This should only be specified if different from the author.

Indicates the person responsible for entering the query into the system. Used when different from the person responsible for the request (author). For example, physician requests administrative assistant to print off a patient's medication profile.

Indicates a potential location for written records, and may also be important for authentication purposes.

The association is optional because in some jurisdictions this information will be conveyed as part of the authentication token.
This should only be specified if different from the location where the event was authored.
Indicates the location where the record of this event was entered.

Indicates where paper records may be located, and may be important to determining authorization.

The association is optional because in some jurisdictions this information will be conveyed as part of the authentication token.
Indicates the service delivery location where the event occurred.
Some systems perform centralized authentication of providers and/or locations. The association is optional because not all systems will make use of a token-based authentication process.
Identifies the authentication token that references information about the people and/or places responsible for the event.

Inferring patient identity opens up the potential for privacy breach through the mis-keying of identifiers. Also, inclusion of patient identity simplifies logging, processing and application of data access constraints such as masking and consent. Finally, patient id is required to support both EHR Index (record and update) and Patient Profile Summary query (list).

Patient identity is key to successful operation of the EHR.

A bare identifier exposes the patient to potential privacy violation.

Associated patient record for which this message applies. Record target can be one of either identified patient (id, name, gender, date of birth), indeterminate patient (name, gender, date of birth) or a patient token (suggesting client identity).
If AuthorizationToken not specified, association is mandatory. If AuthorizationToken specified, association is mandatory if authorization does not cover this participation.
Allows for the trail of responsibility for the action. The association is optional because in some jurisdictions, the supervisor may be conveyed by he authentication token.
Any trigger event can result in errors or may allow for errors to be overridden or managed.
This is the list of clinical and business issues that have been detected and/or managed involving the current action.
On ‘creation’ interactions where the state transition is null->active, contextConductionInd must be true, otherwise it must be false.
Provides information about the thing being created, modified or removed.
If there are multiple subject items, the changes to all of them must be either accepted or rejected as a single action. I.e. One trigger event = 1 unit of work.

Indicates the item(s) being acted upon by this trigger event.

Will be mandatory in wrappers with payload messages, otherwise not present.

Cascading of trigger event objects allows different messages to employ consistent and common objects.

Attribute is mandatory to ensure that cascading will be specified one way or another.

Indicates whether or not objects of the trigger event are to be cascaded to the payload.

If true, associations in the parent act are conducted across the ActRelationship to the message payload (act). Conduction for each association is specifically indicated by each associations' contextControlCode value.

In other words, if the "subject" act relationship has contextConductionInd=true; THEN the dataEnterer association is carried (to the payload) according to the dataEnterer.contextControlCode (AP = propogate to the payload and add to any data enterer(s) already present in the payload).

Provides authorization to record and/or view patient information.

Indicates the consent or keyword used to authorize access or update, including a reason for access; May also be used to override access restriction to the information ('break the glass') on a message by message basis.

May be required on a Prescription Request to indicate a keyword for drug utilization processing.

This will usually only be populated for queries, but could be used for updates if a jurisdiction requires consent before recording information in the EHR (e.g. consent to participate in electronic data exchange).

Note: keywords canot be passed from one application to another via the EHR (e.g. prescriber to dispenser via a Drug Information System).
Information pertaining to a patient's agreement/acceptance to have his/her clinical information electronically stored and shared.

If true, associations in the parent act are conducted across the ActRelationship to the message payload (act). Conduction for each association is specifically indicated by each associations' contextControlCode value.

Allows direction of messages within complex applications. This association is optional because not all applications will require this level of routing.
Provides information on how the message should be routed within the receiving application.
Allows categorization of routing types or support for multiple route pieces. Mandatory to understand the routing information.
A particular type of guidance for routing the message.
Allows internal routing within an application.
Indicates the specific value used to route the item.
Carries the information intended to be conveyed to the receiving application
The content of the message.
soap:Header\wsa:From\@endpointID
Because this is the key identifier of where the message is intended to go, this attribute is mandatory.
The unique identifier of the application or system to whom the message is being routed.
Provides useful information when debugging.
This is the name associated with the system or application sending the message.
Provides additional information that may assist in debugging interactions.
Provides additional information about the configuration of the sending application. Useful when debugging.
Can help to isolate the source of a problem when debugging.
Indicates the last time the sending application was modified or reconfigured.
May be used to filter messages based on the compliance testing of the sending software.
Indicates the version number of the piece of software used to construct the message.
May be used to filter messages based on sending application compliance testing.
Indicates the name of the software used to construct the message.
soap:Header\wsa:To\@endpointID
Used for routing and for verification that "yes, this message is intended for me." This is mandatory because it is the key identifier of the receiving application.
The unique identifier of the application to which the message is being sent.
Optional name of the receiver application.
Name of the receiver application.
Provides support for directing responses to applications other than the original sender.
The system to which responses are to be directed.
soap:Header\wsa:ReplyTo\@endpointID
Allows unique identification and routing to the application to be responded to. This attribute is mandatory be cause it is the principal identifier of the application to respond to.
The unique identifier of the applications to which responses should be sent. Only populated when different from the sending application id.
Conveys information about the interaction and how it is to be processed
The root class of all messages.
soap:Header\wsa:MessageID
Allows detection of duplicate messages, and allows tying acknowledgments to the message they are acknowledging. The attribute is therefore mandatory.
A unique identifier for the message.

Allows identification of how current the information in a message is. Also provides a baseline for identifying the time-zone of other times within the message. As a result, the attribute is mandatory.
Indicates the time this particular message instance was constructed.
Allows jurisdictions and applications to communicate authentication and session information. The attribute is optional because not all jurisdictions will require this capability.
A locally-defined field used to maintain a session, identify a user, and/or perform some other function related to authenticating the message source.
soap:Header\wsa:Action (after the second underscore, if any, “D” otherwise)
Essential to determining receiver behavior and therefore mandatory.
Identifies whether the response is desired immediately (as a direct acknowledgement), on a deferred basis (as a subsequent independent interaction) or via queue using polling.
soap:Header\wsa:To\ (portion between last “\” and second-last “\”)
Needed to know how to validate message definition, CMET definition, vocabulary and other information and is therefore mandatory.
Indicates the version of the messaging standard being referenced.
soap:Header\wsa:Action (after “urn:hl7-org:v3:” and before the second underscore, if any)
Identifies what the receiving application should do, and how the message should be validated. The attribute is therefore mandatory.
Indicates the interaction conveyed by this message.
Indicates any additional validation that may be appropriate. Also influences what extensions can be processed.
Identifies the conformance profile(s) this message complies with.
soap:Header\wsa:To\(portion between second-last “\” and third-last “\”)
Indicates how the message should be handled and is therefore mandatory.
Indicates whether this message is intended to be processed as production, test or debug message.
Provides support for immediate, deferred and polling mode and distinguishes which mode is desired. The attribute is therefore mandatory.
When using SOAP, this attribute MUST be set to NE (Never). (Accept acknowledgements are handled via the transport protocol, not HL7.)
Indicates how the message is expected to be acknowledged.
The identifier is the only non-structural attribute in this class and is therefore mandatory. The association from sending device to agent is optional.
Sending organization unique identifier.
The identifier is the only non-structural attribute in this class and is therefore mandatory. The association from receiver device to agent is optional.
Unique identifier for the receiver organization.
soap:Header\wsa:To
Indicates where the message should be sent. This is optional because not all environments require network addresses. It is mandatory when communicating using SOAP.
The address to which this message is being sent.

In complex routing environments, the acknowledgements may need to be sent to a system other than the one which constructed the original message. This association is optional because not all environments will support responses to systems other than the original sender.
Indicates the interaction that should receive the response to this interaction. Used when different from the sender of the original interaction.
soap:Header\wsa:ReplyTo
Needed when the address to respond to is different than that of the sender. This is optional because not all environments require network addresses. It is required when communicating using SOAP.
Indicates the address to send acknowledgments of this message to.
soap:Header\wsa:From

May be important for sender validation. Usually also the address to which responses are sent. This is optional because not all environments require network addresses. It is mandatory when communicating using SOAP.
The network address of the application which sent the message.
Property-contextConductionStyle: I
Key to understanding whether the interaction has been successful and is therefore mandatory.
Indicates whether the previous interaction was successfully processed.
Indicates to a system how many polled messages are available without the need so send a separate query. The element is optional because not all systems will support polling.
For applications which support polling, indicates the total number of messages waiting to be retrieved.
The priority of the waiting message may influence how quickly the polling system may choose to download queued messages. The element is optional because not all systems will support polling.
Indicates the priority of the highest-priority message that is waiting on the poll queue for the system being responded to.
Allows identification issues related to the parsing and low-level processing of the message.
An error, warning or information message associated with the message being acknowledged.
Different types of messages have substantially different ramifications.
Distinguishes between errors, warnings and information messages.

By providing coded identification of issues and errors, allows applications to have logic that manages particular errors and warnings automatically. However in some circumstances, a code may not be available. Therefore the attribute is marked as 'populated'.

The coding strength is CWE (coded with extensions). The use of local codes is only permitted when those codes are submitted to the SC for consideration and if the SC makes a recommendation other then adoption of the local code, jurisdictions are bound to adopt the recommendation.
Indicates the specific issue represented by this message.
Allows supplementing the 'computer' information for human-readability.
The human-readable description of the error, warning or information message. May convey additional details not present in the 'code', but is not intended to be human-processable.
Allows syntax and other messages to be linked to particular fields within the message.

For XML, the string will be the simple XPath needed to reach the message element. Simple XPath has the format: ("/" "@"?elementName "[" occurrence "]")+

I.e. only the default 'child' axis is permitted, occurrence numbers are always specified, and no other predicates are permitted.
Indicates the location of the elements within the message instance that triggered this error, warning or information message.
Allows direction of messages within complex applications. This association is optional because not all applications will require this level of routing.
Provides information on how the message should be routed within the receiving application.
Allows categorization of routing types or support for multiple route pieces. Mandatory to understand the routing information.
A particular type of guidance for routing the message.
Allows internal routing within an application.
Indicates the specific value used to route the item.
Carries the information intended to be conveyed to the receiving application
The content of the message.

packageLocation.name: QUQI_MT020000AB
packageLocation.desc: Query Request Wrapper - Human Initiated Patient Specific

annotation.text: Property-contextConductionStyle: C
If AuthorizationToken is specified and communicates author, the bare AuthorRole class must be specified, otherwise the R_ActingPerson CMET must be specified.
Critical for auditing and for validating permissions and therefore mandatory.
Indicates the person responsible for the event that caused this message.
Value should always be AUT
The time a change is made is a critical piece of audit information and is therefore mandatory.

The time the person responsible for the event made the decision for it to occur. This may be different than the time the change became effective. (E.g. If a provider decides today to put a prescription on hold starting next Tuesday, the time of creation would be today and the change effective period would be next Tuesday.)

This date can be back-dated.
May have ramifications for the audit trail and reliability of the information.
Indicates how the person who recorded the event became aware of it.. E.g. Verbal, written, fax, etc.
Digital signatures may be needed for authentication of message content. The attribute is marked as optional because it is not yet clear whether there is a use-case for this, or where it will be used.
Indicates the formal digital signature of the message content.

This is a messaging artifact used by HL7 to allow the time, signiture and method to be captured when the author is not sent. This will happen in circumstances where the author information is sent as part of the authentication token.

If specified, then the concepts covered by the token must not be specified (i.e. at least one participation of author, dataEnterer, responsibleParty, location and dataEntryLocation must not be specified)
Only one of Id or Text must be specified.
Conveys information related to the individuals and/or locations involved with the action in situations where the authentication happens on a one-time basis rather than on a per-message basis.

Conveys an authentication token associated with the event.

The token may represent one or all of the following concepts: author, dataEnterer, responsibleParty, location and dataEntryLocation.
GUIDs are an effective way of conveying a temporary authentication token

An authorization token expressed as a GUID.

The Authorization token may represent the concepts of author, data enterer, supervisor (responsible party), responsible location and/or data entry location.
Some systems may choose to use a hashcode or other approach to token construction.

An authentication token expressed as a non-GUID string.

The Authorization token may represent the concepts of author, data enterer, supervisor (responsible party), responsible location and/or data entry location.
Allows linking records to encounters, condition and care-based compositions. Useful for searching and navigation of the patient's record.

A care composition is a record, which summarizes the events that happened during care including who is responsible for the care provided.

Examples include encounters, health condition (episode)-based collections and general care-based collections such as "gynecological care".
Key to understanding what action a message represents.
There may be constraints on the usage of the effectiveTime and reasonCode attributes in the definition of the interaction or the trigger events which are conveyed with this wrapper.
Identifies the action that resulted in this message being sent.
Allows the event to be referenced (for undos) and also indicates whether multiple interactions were caused by the same triggering event. Also used for audit purposes.
Identifier needs to be persisted by receiving applications, except for queries (queries cannot be retracted or undone).

A unique identifier for this particular event assigned by the system in which the event occurred. The identifier must be unique and different from the event identifier that is present on the request - it must be generated by the responding application.
This is mandatory because it is essential to understanding the meaning of the event.
Identifies the trigger event that occurred.
Required for completeness of specification.
Describes the status of the control act, which is always complete (it happened).

The time an event becomes effective may differ from the time the event is recorded (i.e. it may be in the future or the past). For events such as 'suspend', an intended end date may also be indicated.
Indicates the time the event (e.g. query, change, activation) should begin and occasionally when it should end.
Allows identifying a reason for a specific action, such as 'reason for hold' or 'reason for accessing information'.
The domain associated with this attribute will vary for each interaction and will be noted as part of the interaction description.
Identifies why this specific message interaction (e.g. query, activation request, modification request) occurred.

Important for audit information and determining permissions.

The association is optional because in some jurisdictions this information will be conveyed as part of the authentication token.
This should only be specified if different from the author.

Indicates the person responsible for entering the query into the system. Used when different from the person responsible for the request (author). For example, physician requests administrative assistant to print off a patient's medication profile.

Indicates a potential location for written records, and may also be important for authentication purposes.

The association is optional because in some jurisdictions this information will be conveyed as part of the authentication token.
This should only be specified if different from the location where the event was authored.
Indicates the location where the record of this event was entered.

Indicates where paper records may be located, and may be important to determining authorization.

The association is optional because in some jurisdictions this information will be conveyed as part of the authentication token.
Indicates the service delivery location where the event occurred.
Used to filter the information returned by the query. All queries must have parameters, therefore this element is mandatory.
References the parameter names and the values used by the query.
Some systems perform centralized authentication of providers and/or locations. The association is optional because not all systems will make use of a token-based authentication process.
Identifies the authentication token that references information about the people and/or places responsible for the event.
Needed to allow continuation of queries and linking of query requests and responses and therefore mandatory.
Unique number for this particular query.

Intended to convey the requested 'packaging' of query results. This attribute does not affect which rows are selected by the query, just the manner in which they are returned. For example, a batch file containing responses, a response message containing multiple payloads, or a stream of response messages (notifications) each identifying itself as a response to a query request.
This allows the sender to indicate to the receiver that this query should follow an expedited processing flow.

Inferring patient identity opens up the potential for privacy breach through the mis-keying of identifiers. Also, inclusion of patient identity simplifies logging, processing and application of data access constraints such as masking and consent. Finally, patient id is required to support both EHR Index (record and update) and Patient Profile Summary query (list).

Patient identity is key to successful operation of the EHR.

A bare identifier exposes the patient to potential privacy violation.

Choice of Patient CMET is as follows:

COCT_MT050201CA 'identified' when supporting Patient Session Tokens.

COCT_MT050207CA 'informational' when passing through non Client- Registry patient for PHS or similar processing.

COCT_MT050202CA 'identified-confirmable' otherwise.

Associated patient record for which this message applies. Record target can be one of either identified patient (id, name, gender, date of birth), indeterminate patient (name, gender, date of birth) or a patient token (suggesting client identity).

Important for audit information and determining permissions.

The association is optional because in some jurisdictions this information will be conveyed as part of the authentication token
Allows for the trail of responsibility for the action. The association is optional because in some jurisdictions, the supervisor may be conveyed by he authentication token.
Any trigger event can result in errors or may allow for errors to be overridden or managed.
This is the list of clinical and business issues that have been detected and/or managed involving the current action.

Provides authorization to record and/or view patient information.

Indicates the consent or keyword used to authorize access or update, including a reason for access; May also be used to override access restriction to the information ('break the glass') on a message by message basis.

May be required on a Prescription Request to indicate a keyword for drug utilization processing.

This will usually only be populated for queries, but could be used for updates if a jurisdiction requires consent before recording information in the EHR (e.g. consent to participate in electronic data exchange).

Note: keywords canot be passed from one application to another via the EHR (e.g. prescriber to dispenser via a Drug Information System).
Information pertaining to a patient's agreement/acceptance to have his/her clinical information electronically stored and shared.

packageLocation.name: QUQI_MT120006AB
packageLocation.desc: Query Response Wrapper - Device Initiated Patient Specific

annotation.text: Property-contextConductionStyle: C

Examples include encounters, health condition (episode)-based collections and general care-based collections such as "gynecological care".

This is mandatory because it is essential to understanding the meaning of the event.

Used to filter the information returned by the query. All queries must have parameters, therefore this element is mandatory.
References the parameter names and the values used by the query.
Allows linking of a response back to the request that triggered it and is therefore mandatory. Particularly useful when responses are deferred or queued.
Identifies the query being acknowledged
Used to control receiver logic and is therefore mandatory.
Indicates whether the query was successful or not.
Indicates the overall size of the result-set and is therefore mandatory. Particularly useful when only part of the result set is actually returned.
Identifies the total number of rows identified that matched the query.
Provides a quick overview of the results of the query and is therefore mandatory.
Identifies the number of rows returned as part of this particular query response.
Identifies how much data remains to be queried and is therefore mandatory.
Indicates the number of rows that still exist after the last row returned in this response.
Needed to allow continuation of queries and linking of query requests and responses and therefore mandatory.
Unique number for this particular query.

Intended to convey the 'packaging' of query results. This attribute does not affect which rows are selected by the query, just the manner in which they are returned. For example, a batch file containing responses, a response message containing multiple payloads, or a stream of response messages (notifications) each identifying itself as a response to a query request.

Finally, patient id is required to support both EHR Index (record and update) and Patient Profile Summary query (list).

A bare identifier exposes the patient to potential privacy violation.

Any trigger event can result in errors or may allow for errors to be overridden or managed.
This is the list of clinical and business issues that have been detected and/or managed involving the current action.
Provides information about the thing being created, modified or removed.
If there are multiple subject items, the changes to all of them must be either accepted or rejected as a single action. I.e. One trigger event = 1 unit of work.

Indicates the item(s) being acted upon by this trigger event.

Will be mandatory in wrappers with payload messages, otherwise not present.

Cascading of trigger event objects allows different messages to employ consistent and common objects.

Attribute is mandatory to ensure that cascading will be specified one way or another.

Indicates whether or not objects of the trigger event are to be cascaded to the payload.

If true, associations in the parent act are conducted across the ActRelationship to the message payload (act). Conduction for each association is specifically indicated by each associations' contextControlCode value.

In other words, if the "subject" act relationship has contextConductionInd=true; THEN the subjectOf association is carried (to the regsitrationEvent act) according to the subjectOf.contextControlCode (AP = propogate to the reg event and add to any subject(s) (issues) already present).

Provides authorization to record and/or view patient information.

Indicates the consent or keyword used to authorize access or update, including a reason for access; May also be used to override access restriction to the information ('break the glass') on a message by message basis.

May be required on a Prescription Request to indicate a keyword for drug utilization processing.

This will usually only be populated for queries, but could be used for updates if a jurisdiction requires consent before recording information in the EHR (e.g. consent to participate in electronic data exchange).

Note: keywords canot be passed from one application to another via the EHR (e.g. prescriber to dispenser via a Drug Information System).
Information pertaining to a patient's agreement/acceptance to have his/her clinical information electronically stored and shared.
Property-contextConductionStyle: C
Included to maintain conformance with HL7 UV models. Sent as a nullFlavor of 'UNK' (Unknown) as this information is not captured in the Netcare document repositories.
The jurisdictional identifier assigned to the author of the clinical document.
Provides information about the author of the clinical document.
The date and time that the clinical document was authored.
Provides information about the repository where the clinical document resides.
This in an extension to the HL7 UV model to meet business needs in AB.
The name of the data source that provided the clinical document.
Contains information about the clinical document
The repository-assigned identifier associated with the clinical document.
A coded value used to categorize the clinical document.
The title of the clinical document.
A coded value indicating the status of a clinical document - i.e. complete vs. interim.
The date of the clinical document.

Included to maintain conformance with HL7 UV models. Sent as a nullFlavor of 'NA' (Not Applicable) as this information is set at the patient level and not captured in the Netcare document repositories.
A coded value that indicates the masking status associated with a clinical document.
Report version number from the repository.
Information about the administrative observations related to the clinical document.
A coded value indicating the type of administrative observation (e.g. patient mismatch) that is being communicated.
The actual value of the administrative observation.
Provides information about the data source that provided the clinical document.
The name of the provider that authored the clinical document.
Provides information about administrative-related information (e.g. patient mismatch iindicator) for a clinical document.
Provides information about the patient whose record contains the clinical document.
The identifer associated with the repository in which the clinical document is stored.
A coded value that represents the procedure being documented.
Property-contextConductionStyle: C
Included to maintain conformance with HL7 UV models. Sent as a nullFlavor of 'UNK' (Unknown) as this information is not captured in the Netcare document repositories.
The jurisdictional identifier assigned to the author of the clinical document.
Provides information about the person that authenticated the clinical document - i.e. the person that validated that the information contained within the clinical document is correct.
The date that the clinical document was authenticated.
Included to maintain conformance with HL7 UV model. Sent as a nullFlavor of 'NA' (Not Applicable) as this is not currently captured in Netcare report repositories.
A code specifying whether and how the authenticator has attested his authentication through a signature and or whether such a signature is needed.
Provides information about the author of the clinical document.
The date and time that the clinical document was authored.
Provides information about the repository where the clinical document resides.
Provides information about the person who transcribed the clinical document.
The date that the clinical document was transcribed.
This in an extension to the HL7 UV model to meet business needs in AB.
The name of the data source that provided the clinical document.
Contains information about the clinical document
The repository-assigned identifier associated with the clinical document.
A coded value used to categorize the clinical document.
The title of the clinical document.
The full clinical document embedded as a MIME-encoded attachment.
A coded value indicating the status of a clinical document - i.e. complete vs. interim.
The date of the clinical document.

Included to maintain conformance with HL7 UV models. Sent as a nullFlavor of 'NA' (Not Applicable) as this information is set at the patient level and not captured in the Netcare document repositories.
A coded value that indicates the masking status associated with a clinical document.
Version number of the report being requested. Used to determine if the version requested is different from the version possessed.
Information about the administrative observations related to the clinical document.
A coded value indicating the type of administrative observation (e.g. patient mismatch) that is being communicated.
The actual value of the administrative observation.
Provides information about the data source that provided the clinical document.
Provides information about the facility or location that is the intended recipient of the clinical document.
Included to maintain conformance with HL7 UV models. Sent as a nullFlavor of 'UNK' (Unknown) as this information is not captured in the Netcare document repositories.
The identifier of the organization that is the intended recipient of the clinical document.
The name of the facility or location that is the intended recipient of the clinical document.
Provides context for the document. In the future, may also allow for automated routing of documents to their intended recipients.
Identifies the people and facilities that the document was written for or is intended to be sent to.
The name of the provider that authored, authenticated, transcriber or is the intended recipient of the clinical document.
Provides information about administrative-related information (e.g. patient mismatch iindicator) for a clinical document.
Provides information about the patient whose record contains the clinical document.
The identifer associated with the repository in which the clinical document is stored.
A coded value that represents the documented procedure
Property-contextConductionStyle: I
Allows retrieving those documents in which a particular was the author.
Filters the documents retrieved to only include those where the identified provider was the author. If unspecified, no filter is applied.

Allows constraining the type of records to be retrieved. Multiple repetitions are present to allow selection of multiple types with a single query.

This element makes use of the CD datatype to allow for use of the SNOMED code system that in some circumstances requires the use of post-coordination. Post-coordination is only supported by the CD datatype.

Filters the type(s) or category(ies) of the documents to be retrieved. The query will return both those records whose type exactly matches, as well as those whose types are subsets of the specified parameter. If no Types are specified, no restriction will be placed on the types to be returned.

Query results should include those with an match of this code, as well those matching any specializations of the coded parameter.

Allows constraining the retrieved records to those applicable at a particular time. Useful in retrieving those records "currently in effect" as well as retrieving views of what information was in effect at some point in the past.

Filters the set of records to be retrieved to those which occurred or were effective for the patient within the time boundaries specified. Either the lower bound or upper bound or both would be specified. If no value is specified, no filter will be applied. If there is any overlap between the specified time-range and the effective time of the record, the record will be returned.
Allows the user and/or the point-of-service application to constrain what EHR information they wish to retrieve.
Identifies the various parameters that act as filters on the records to be retrieved.
Property-contextConductionStyle: I

Specifically identifies the Document to be returned.

Because the primary purpose of the query is to retrieve identified documents, the element is mandatory.
A globally unique identifier assigned by the EHR to the Document to be retrieved.
Allows the user and/or the point-of-service application to constrain what EHR information they wish to retrieve.
Identifies the various parameters that act as filters on the records to be retrieved.
Repository Name is returned as part of the Document List (DocumentEvent) query response.
The identifier of the EHR repository.

Included to maintain conformance with HL7 UV models. Sent as a nullFlavor of 'UNK' (Unknown) as this information is not captured in the Netcare document repositories.
The jurisdictional identifier assigned to the author of the clinical document subscription request.
An identifier associated with the recipient of the information update. Examples include: provider ID, eDlivery mailbox, etc.

Provides information about the repository where the clinical document resides.

The date that the clinical document was authenticated.

A code specifying whether and how the authenticator has attested his authentication through a signature and or whether such a signature is needed.
Provides information about the author of the clinical document.
The date and time that the clinical document was authored.

Provides information about the person who transcribed the clinical document.
The date that the clinical document was transcribed.
This in an extension to the HL7 UV model to meet business needs in AB.
The name of the data source that provided the clinical document.

The repository-assigned identifier associated with the clinical document.
A coded value used to categorize the clinical document.
The title of the clinical document.
The full clinical document embedded as a MIME-encoded attachment.

The date of the clinical document.

Provides context for the document. In the future, may also allow for automated routing of documents to their intended recipients.
Identifies the people and facilities that the document was written for or is intended to be sent to.
The name of the provider that authored, authenticated, transcriber or is the intended recipient of the clinical document.

Property-contextConductionStyle: C
Need a harmonization approval to make ActMoodCompletionTrack specializable
One of the primary purposes of a care composition is to 'group' information. This attribute is the representation of that grouping.
References existing health service event records that are associated this care composition
The provider responsible for admitting a patient to a hospital or other inpatient facility.
The provider who had primary responsibility for the patient during the encounter.

Used to identify responsibility for accuracy and relevance of the information. This association reflects primary responsibility (which is expected to be known), and is therefore populated.

The author is generally the person to contact with requests for additional information. In some cases, this information may also be used for filtering or sorting.

This identifies the provider who is responsible for the decision to capture the Care Composition in the patient's EHR. Note that while the author is frequently the data-enterer, this will not always be the case, for example where transcribers are involved.

Care compositions provide a means of navigating a patient's EHR by grouping related records together into identified "collections".

Multiple repetitions are allowed so that a single Care Composition can be attached to multiple encounters, condition-based (episode) and care-based collections.

This identifies the encounter-based, condition-based and/or other care-based collections that the Care Composition is considered to be part of. Care Compositions can be defined as part of other care compositions.
UpdateMode constrained to "Add" and "Remove"
References existing health service event records that are associated this care composition
A provider who is consulted during the course of an encounter.
These are key elements in defining the encounter.
Describes the health conditions which were identified or determined as part of the encounter.
Code is fixed to DX if not using SNOMED

Identifies this observation as a type of diagnosis and is therefore mandatory.

This element makes use of the CD datatype to allow for use of the SNOMED code system that in some circumstances requires the use of post-coordination. Post-coordination is only supported by the CD datatype.
Identifies the type of diagnosis

Allows tracking outcomes and provides key information about the encounter

This element makes use of the CD datatype to allow for use of the SNOMED code system that in some circumstances requires the use of post-coordination. Post-coordination is only supported by the CD datatype.
A coded form of the condition that was identified as part of the care delivery described by this care composition.

Provides a point of contact for follow-up. The discharging provider generally has the best sense of the complete set of care associated with the encounter because they have generally reviewed the complete set of records in constructing a discharge or care summary. They also generally take the responsibility for ensuring the safe transition of the patient back into the community environment or whatever other care setting the patient transitions to.
Indicates the provider who made the decision to end the encounter.
Must not be specified when Care Composition Type is 'Condition-based'

The site of the actual event provides context for interpreting the record. In some cases, it may also provide follow-up information

Multiple repetitions are allowed for telehealth and other remote encounters.

This identifies the location where the Care Composition actually occurred. E.g. Patient's residence, clinic, work site, etc. It only needs to be specified when the occurrence location differs from the official record location.

In circumstances where number of locations involved is greater than the limit supported by the message, multiple encounters should be used.

These are key search criteria for encounters and provide a good high-level understanding of the activity within an encounter without needing to look at the details. However, they are only 'required' because discharge diagnosis are not gathered for every encounter.

Identifies any health conditions that have been newly identified in the patient as part of the encounter or which have been implicated as contributing to the need for the encounter. Discharge diagnosis represents "what is known or understood" as a result of the activities and observations that have taken place during the encounter.

Care compositions allow grouping together numerous related records which aids searching and navigation. Also, the mere knowledge that a type of care has occurred or is occurring (e.g. an in-patient hospital encounter) can be useful information when delivering subsequent care.

A care composition is a record with two purposes. It indicates that care of a given type has occurred or is occurring. It also acts as a collector for the events that happened during care, including who is responsible for the care provided.

Care composition messages may be sent during the course of care to describe the progress of care or may be sent at the termination of care to describe all the activities that occurred during the provision of care. Note that this record merely captures the existence of care and the locations and people involved. The actual discrete events and any care summary documentation that results are captured using other messages.

Examples include: encounters, condition-related care (episodes) and longer-term care collections such as "gynecological care".

Care Composition Type is used for searching and for organizing Care Composition records as well as sorting them for presentation.

This is a key attribute for understanding the type of record and is therefore mandatory.

Identifies the type of Care Composition represented by this record.

Care Composition is the generic name given to event 'containers' such as Encounters, Health-Condition-based Collections (Episodes) and Care-based Collections. The "type" of care composition places constraints on what elements are supported.

Encounter-based collection: a series of health care events that occur during an interaction between one or more health care providers and one or more patients where the providers and the patient remain in the same location over a contiguous period of time; the providers and patient may be at different locations (telehealth). e.g. Inpatient encounter, Community encounter.

Condition-based collection (Episode): a series of interactions between a patient and one or more health care providers over time in one or more locations and tied together by a common diagnosis or problem.

Care-based collection: a high level grouping of health events, encounters, and/or episodes related to a particular area of healthcare. e.g. Gynecology care, Cardiology Care, etc.

This is primarily used to supersede records where an assertion was made that is subsequently determined to be false. It is important to be able to make explicit statements that something is known to not be true.

This element is mandatory because it should always be known whether the record is being refuted or not.
When set to true, specifically flags the Care Composition record as "did not occur". The default is false. Additional details about the reasons for refuting the record may be conveyed in notes.

Status is frequently used to filter query responses as well as to sort records for presentation. It also affects how the Care Composition record is interpreted.

Because the status won't always be known, the attribute is marked as 'populated' to allow the use of null flavors.

This identifies the current state of the Care Composition record. Allowed status values are 'active' (the encounter, episode or general delivery of care ongoing) and 'completed' (the encounter, episode or general care has ended).

Identifies the time-period of relevance to the record that is useful in filtering and organizing "time-view" presentations of data. Because the timing information won't always be known, this attribute is marked as 'populated'.

Represents the start and end of the date/time interval during which the care described by the composition was/is being provided.

E.g. The admission and discharge date/time; the date on which the episode began and ended; etc.

Please note that it is possible for many episodes and care events to not have an end date; in these situations, only the start date will be specified. Even encounters will not have an end date until the encounter is completed/patient is discharged.

The person who makes the decision to capture information in the electronic record is not always the person who actually performed the action. Knowledge of the performer is useful both for tracking responsibility and for subsequent follow-up. Multiple repetitions are allowed for those circumstances where more than one provider is involved.

If not specified, it is assumed that the author is also the performer. I.e. If the author and performer are the same, only the author should be sent. If the author is not the performer, but the performer is not known, a null flavor of UNK (unknown) should be used.

Identifies the person who actually performed the action described in the record.

For outpatient encounters, identifies the provider(s) with principle responsibility for the encounter. For inpatient/institutional encounters, this generally isn't used (admitting and discharge providers are captured elsewhere).

For condition-based (episode) collections and care-based collections, identifies the provider(s) currently responsible for managing the episode or type of care (may change over time) described by this record.

NOTE: This is *not* intended to capture all providers involved in care, merely those responsible for care. In most circumstances this will only be one provider. However, in some circumstances (e.g. telehealth) it may be necessary to capture more than one.

In circumstances where number of providers involved is greater than the limit supported by the message, multiple encounters should be used.
A provider who requested the encounter.

Identity of the provider who holds clinical responsibility for the encounter (e.g. a supervising physician can have responsibility for an encounter performed by an intern). The performing provider and responsible provider may be the same person.
Allows for additional free-text comments to be communicated. Such notes can be added by the provider at the time the record is created and by any provider at any time after the record is created.
This indicates comments that providers have recorded about the Care Composition.
